docs.lead_paragraph: Shirley Kindle, a 65-year-old retired clerical worker, played a bit part in Al Gore's presidential campaign today, but it was enough to win her over to the vice president's side. Ms. Kindle needs a dozen prescription drugs each month for diabetes and other ailments. All told, they cost more than $500 a month, which is more than her Social Security check. To keep up her regimen, she has borrowed money from her family, although, like many other elderly people on fixed incomes, she sometimes skips certain drugs altogether because she cannot afford them.

headline.main: Retiree With High Drug Bills Lends a Hand to Gore

docs.abstract: Vice Pres Al Gore visits drug store in East Hartford, Conn, accompanied by Shirley Kindle, 65, to re-enact her monthly drug purchase of $506.34; event is part of coordinated effort with White House to demonstrate their concern that drug prices are soaring; Kindle says she likes Gore's proposal that Medicare cover cost of prescription drugs; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Shirley Kindle, a 65-year-old retired clerical worker, played a bit part in Al Gore's presidential campaign today, but it was enough to win her over to the vice president's side.    Ms. Kindle needs a dozen prescription drugs each month for diabetes...

docs.lead_paragraph: A New Jersey man was charged yesterday with bilking the Medicare system of $40 million by submitting false claims through ambulance companies he ran secretly. The man, Hugh Nastasi, who was arrested Monday night at his home in Brick, N.J., was convicted in 1989 in a fraud case and barred from taking part in Medicare or Medicaid for 25 years. But he secretly owned and ran at least four ambulance companies after leaving prison in 1990, said Loretta Lynch, a United States Attorney in Brooklyn. Prosecutors said Medicare had paid the businesses about $40 million since 1992.

headline.main: U.S. Charges Man With Medicare Fraud

docs.abstract: Hugh Nastasi of Brick, NJ, is charged with bilking Medicare system of $40 million by submitting false claims through ambulance companies he ran secretly (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Seeking to push citywide labor negotiations forward, the Giuliani administration presented its first formal contract proposals yesterday, but the union local that received the proposals, one that represents school safety officers and Housing Authority workers, called the proposals an insult. The city's labor commissioner, James F. Hanley, who has been overseeing the city's labor negotiations, presented a package that called for no across-the-board pay increases, with all raises coming instead in the form of individualized merit pay. The city also called for the workers to pay part of their health insurance premiums; the city now covers 100 percent of those premiums.

headline.main: City Presents Labor Proposals But Union Says It Is Insulted

docs.abstract: Giulaini administration, seeking to push citywide labor negotiations forward, presents its first formal contract proposals to Teamsters Local 237, but union calls proposals 'an insult' (M)
docs.snippet: Seeking to push citywide labor negotiations forward, the Giuliani administration presented its first formal contract proposals yesterday, but the union local that received the proposals, one that represents school safety officers and Housing...

docs.lead_paragraph: Prices for the 50 drugs most frequently used by older Americans increased last year at nearly twice the rate of inflation, a study to be issued on Wednesday at the White House says. The study found a similar trend over the last six years.

headline.main: Administration Using Study To Push Elderly Drug Plan

docs.abstract: White House to release study showing that prices for 50 drugs most used by older Americans increased 3.9 percent last year, nearly twice inflation rate, with similar trends over last six years; Pres Clinton to cite data in urging Congress to enact Medicare drug benefit; drug makers admit raising prices but say drugs still offer excellent value (M)
docs.snippet: Prices for the 50 drugs most frequently used by older Americans increased last year at nearly twice the rate of inflation, a study to be issued on Wednesday at the White House says.    The study found a similar trend over the last six years.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: It is not evident, as one expert states in your April 21 front-page article, that home health care is cheaper than inpatient care. The national average hospital occupancy ratio is about 65 percent. Having armies of home care workers traveling to geographically disparate locations to visit patients requires more resources than would be needed to care for the same patients, if they were concentrated at half-empty hospitals.
docs.abstract: Prof Uwe E Reinhardt letter disputes April 21 article in which health expert stated that home health care is cheaper than in patient care
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    It is not evident, as one expert states in your April 21 front-page article, that home health care is cheaper than inpatient care.     The national average hospital occupancy ratio is about 65 percent. Having armies of home care...

docs.lead_paragraph: The Vermont House of Representatives gave its final approval today to a bill creating same-sex marriages in almost everything but the name. The State Senate approved the bill last week, and Gov. Howard Dean said he would sign it into law within days. The 79-to-68 vote to create civil unions set off sighs of relief, tears and hugs among the three same-sex couples whose 1997 lawsuit seeking the right to marry led to this moment. Throughout the morning's debate, one couple, Nina Beck and Stacy Jolles, stood holding their baby son, Seth, beneath a portrait of George Washington. Moments after the vote, Ms. Jolles turned to Ms. Beck and offered a new version of the traditional proposal: ''C.U. me!''

headline.main: Vermont Gives Final Approval to Same-Sex Unions

docs.abstract: Vermont House approves bill creating civil unions for same-sex couples; bill, to be signed by Gov Howard Dean, gives same-sex couples virtually all rights and responsibilities of married couples, from health insurance to inheritance rights; couples will have to register with town clerk, have unions certified by clergy member or justice of the peace, and go through family court to dissolve unions; bill responds to state Supreme Court ruling in December, and is not expected to be recognized in other states or to entitle partners to federal benefits; photos of two lesbian couples (M)
docs.snippet: The Vermont House of Representatives gave its final approval today to a bill creating same-sex marriages in almost everything but the name. The State Senate approved the bill last week, and Gov. Howard Dean said he would sign it into law within days....

docs.lead_paragraph: In the feverish world of horse racing and breeding, mosquito season is about as welcome as a hurricane at the Preakness. Especially this spring, given the prospect of a repeat of the West Nile virus -- which killed seven people and nine horses in New York last year, including a retired racehorse who was to breed thoroughbreds. The possibility that the mosquito-borne illness could destroy a multimillion-dollar celebrity like Fusaichi Pegasus, the Kentucky Derby favorite who spent four days training at Aqueduct before winning the Wood Memorial there on April 15, has track officials more hyper than in-bred thoroughbreds.

headline.main: A Bug That Can Fell a Horse; Fighting Mosquitoes' Threat to Thoroughbreds

docs.abstract: Aqueduct and Belmont Park officials are trying to contain West Nile virus, which killed seven people and nine horses in New York last year; are concerned that mosquito-borne illness will destroy multimillion-dollar race horse; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Laying out his economic vision more fully than ever, Vice President Al Gore offered himself yesterday as a fiscal conservative and steward of the Clinton administration's economic formula and prosperity. His primary goal, he said, was to reduce the national debt year by year -- barring an emergency -- and to set it on a course for complete elimination by the year 2013.

headline.main: Gore Says Top Goal Is Steady Reduction of Nation's Debt

docs.abstract: Vice Pres Gore portrays himself as fiscal conservative and steward of Clinton administration's economic prosperity, speech to Assn for a Better New York; photo; says primary goal is to reduce national debt by year 2013; pledges to shore up Social Security, promote tax cuts for college savings, job retraining, health insurance and long-term care; vows 'aggressive' free trade efforts; declares opponent George W Bush would shatter economic confidence, give too much to the wealthy and drive nation into inflation and recession; recalls economic problems of Bush's father's presidency (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: I applaud Medicare for its plan to investigate preventive medicine by financing a study using Dr. Dean Ornish's diet plan with elderly heart patients (''Medicare to Run Diet Experiment for Critically Ill,'' April 11). Since Medicare leads the way for other insurance companies, it means that all consumers may stand to benefit from this shift toward coverage for prevention.
docs.abstract: Betsy Taylor letter lauds Medicare for its plan to investigate preventive medicine by financing a study using Dr Dean Ornish's diet plan with elderly heart patients; raises question, however, as to whether Ornish program is too difficult for many people to follow

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: As a psychiatrist, I am appalled at the destruction wrought by the so-called biological revolution in psychiatry (''Growing Up on a Ritalin-Prozac Cocktail''), a revolution driven not by science but by insurance companies demanding a quick fix.
